title: What are the implications of being theologically liberal? - Quora

response.answer_text: You can't be theologically liberal. That's like believing that earth is half round and flat to the other halve, or seriously pondering that one plus two could be five as well. There is no god, so any form of 'theology' is crap. The most despicable thing is that there are so called ‘universities' which ‘teach’ ‘theology' goddie crap to children!!! My dear goat, can you imaging alledged ‘intelligent’ adults doing that? It's almost 2020! Leprechauns, fairies, fortune tellers and goddies, it's all the same.

Being theologically liberal means doing the hard work of thinking for yourself, rather than accepting the simplistic answers that are given to children. It means understanding that ancient peoples may have had important insights into life — because human nature changes very slowly if at all —but that these ancient peoples lacked the tools of science, journalism, and modern historical techniques. By analogy, being theologically liberal is understanding that there was indeed a Saint Nicholas, and we can keep alive the spirit of giving that he epitomized, but that doesn’t mean that Saint Nick is going to come down your chimney. Being theologically liberal means understanding that parts of the Bible may be parables — and that it’s not important whether Jonah was or was not swallowed by a whale… but rather what’s important about that story is that Jonah learned to forgive the people of Nineveh. Being theologically liberal means using the brains that God in His wisdom gave us. And being theologically liberal means believing Jesus when he said that the most important things were love, compassion, forgiveness, and service to others.
